name: 1-octadecylamine
Reason: The basic structure to consider here is n-octadecane, which is a long-chain hydrocarbon with 18 carbon atoms. The melting point of n-octadecane is 28.2°C. Adding an amino group (-NH2) to the end of the chain to form 1-octadecylamine will influence the melting point due to the introduction of hydrogen bonding capabilities. Hydrogen bonding generally increases the melting point because molecules can form stronger intermolecular forces, resulting in a higher amount of energy needed to disrupt these interactions and melt the solid. Given the significant increase in melting point caused by the introduction of an amine group in other aliphatic amines, we can estimate this influence to be approximately +25°C for the molecule in question.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit for the compound is octadecane, which has a melting point of around 16°C. The amine group generally increases the melting point due to the ability to form hydrogen bonds, which can be estimated to add around 20-30°C. However, the long alkyl chain in the compound also increases the melting point due to increased van der Waals forces, which can be estimated to add around 10-20°C. The combined effect of the amine and alkyl chain is expected to increase the melting point significantly.
